entry.title: Re: Request to Update Default Login in Universal ID
entry.content:
Please use the S-user ID instead of the email address to log in. If logged in with an email address, the default S-user will be the one used to log in to SAP ID Service.

For several S-users linked with the same email address, to change the default login S-user: 
1. Access SAP ID Service.
2. Click 'Log Out'.
3. Log in again using the desired S-user ID. 
4. After successfully changing, the updated S-user will appear first.

Detail information please refer to KBA 3650023 - Unable to Select Linked Accounts After Logging into SAP for Me with Universal ID - SAP Universal ID (UID)

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytic Cloud has really limited functionalities...
entry.content:
Hi,

you have raised some very practical points. Many of us who have used Power BI or Tableau notice the same differences when we start working in SAC. Let me share my view in short.

 

🔹 Linked Dimension Limitation

You are right, in SAC the linked dimension must appear in the widget, otherwise the relationship does not work.
This is because SAC treats it as front-end blending, not as a semantic model join like Power BI.

 

🔹 Calculations

SAC is stricter between measures and dimensions.
For complex logic (sum, avg, count, conditions like Sales > 100), you need Restricted/Calculated measures in the model.

 

🔹 Data Models in Stories vs Data Analyzer

Stories are limited to prepared models, so flexibility feels less compared to Power Pivot.
The Data Analyzer allows more OLAP-style exploration, but it is separate from the Story environment.

 

🔹 Where SAC is Stronger

  • SAC ensures consistent governance: calculations and joins are controlled in the model layer, avoiding ad-hoc mismatches.
  • Integration with BW/HANA means business rules and hierarchies are reused directly, unlike Power BI/Tableau where relationships are defined outside the ERP.
  • This approach gives trusted numbers for finance and costing teams, even if flexibility is less for ad-hoc slicing.

 


So yes, SAC feels more rigid compared to Power BI or Tableau, but the trade-off is stronger control, governance, and trusted data when you are working with enterprise systems like BW and S4. It depends on whether you value flexibility or consistency more for your use case.

entry.title: Re: SAC Waterfall Custom Hierarchy Dimension
entry.content:
Hello, thanks for raising this point.

Hierarchy Activation in Model
When you create a custom hierarchy in SAC (like YearMonth), you must first ensure it is enabled in the model. Open the model, go to the Calendar Month dimension, and check if your custom hierarchy is listed and marked as active.

Hierarchy Usage in Story
In the story, after selecting Calendar Month, use the “…” (more options) menu on the chart axis to switch from Flat Presentation to your YearMonth hierarchy. If not switched, the output will look flat even if hierarchy exists.

Validation Step
Also confirm that your hierarchy has at least two levels (for example, Year → Month). If it is a single-level group, SAC will not visually change the chart output.

Hope this helps clarify where to enable and apply the hierarchy. This small step often resolves such display issues quickly.

entry.title: Re: How to get access to the Availability app in SAP for...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

To check the content in the Availability application, your S-user ID must have one of the following authorizations:

  • Display System Data
  • Edit System Data

Kindly refer to KBA 2587408 - S-user ID authorizations for Cloud Availability and Manage Cloud Service Availability Notifications (Get Notified) - SAP for Me.

Please request for the authorizations using the Self-Service authorization request feature per KBA 2891528. 

You may also contact your Super User or user admin directly to get the missing authorizations.

Hope the above information helps.

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Unleashing Creativity with Cloud-Based AI Apps: 2025 Premium Hub CoE High School Summer Orientation
entry.content:
This summer, a group of bright high school students embarked on an exciting journey at SAP's week-long STEM orientation program. This program focused on harnessing the power of cloud-based AI apps using the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), providing students with practical, hands-on learning experiences using low-code/no-code tools.

 

 

Building the Foundation with SAP Build Apps:

The week kicked off with students getting an introduction into SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and Artificial Intelligence at SAP. A key component of the learning experience was SAP Build Apps, a powerful tool within SAP BTP that enabled students to design and develop applications using a low-code/no-code approach. This tool simplified the app creation process, allowing students to focus on functionality and creativity rather than complex coding.

The primary task was to create a barcode scanner application using SAP Build Apps. This app scanned barcodes and retrieved detailed information about food items from the Open Food Facts API, a free and open database of food product information. This integration taught students how to connect their applications to external data sources, demonstrating the potential of combining SAP BTP with other digital resources.

Adding a Generative AI Twist:

The real magic happened when students were introduced to Google Gemini, allowing them to enhance their applications with Generative AI capabilities. By integrating AI into their apps, students were able to analyze the health aspects of food ingredients, transforming simple barcode scanners into intelligent, interactive applications. This exercise encouraged students to think critically about how AI can enhance user experiences and provide valuable insights.

Showcasing Innovation:

As the week progressed, students eagerly worked on their projects, each bringing their own flair to the task. They showcased the culmination of their hard work in a demo session held on Friday, presenting their enhanced applications. It was inspiring to see how each participant leveraged the tools and guidance provided to create something truly remarkable.

Reflecting on the Experience:

The orientation week was not just about building apps; it was about fostering a spirit of innovation and collaboration. The students left with more than just technical skills; they gained confidence and a deeper understanding of how technology can be used to solve real-world problems.

The feedback from participants has been overwhelmingly positive, with many expressing how the program has sparked a new interest in technology and AI.

Here's what one of our students had to say about their unforgettable experience:

“Thank you so much for organizing such a great practicum experience at SAP. I really enjoyed the week and learned a lot, especially”during the project work and all the tours. Getting to explore the SAP Build platform and contribute to the barcode scanner project was a really cool experience, and it helped me understand how tech is used in the real world.

I also really appreciated how friendly and supportive everyone was throughout the week. The tours of the MCC and Smart Factory, as well as the leadership talk on the last day, were really inspiring and gave me a better idea of the kinds of roles I might want to explore in the future.

Thanks again for the opportunity, and I’m really grateful for the experience!”- Mehul Vijayvergiya

 

Looking Forward:

This orientation was a testament to the power of education and technology in shaping the minds of tomorrow's innovators. As we continue to provide these opportunities, we are excited to see how these young minds will contribute to the ever-evolving tech landscape.

 

Thank you to Balaji Rao Gaddam for sponsoring and hosting this year’s event.  

Thank you to the SAP colleagues who coordinated this year’s Summer Orientation and made it a success!

 

Ashok Kumar M & Megan Rech (Leads) Nkem Ohanenye (Project Co-Coordinator), Savannah Cole (HR) and volunteers and speakers. A huge thank you to our onsite team coordinators Nkem Ohanenye, Sean David, Prasad Gagarani, and Manas Trivedi.


And a special thanks to the SAP speakers and colleagues who shared their expertise!
John Astill (D-Shop Demo), Evan Taylor (STAR Internship Program), Justin Lynch (SAP Overview & Career Development), George Harwood (NSQ Campus Tour), Haibo Huang & Vivek RR (Artificial Intelligence Experts), SooWan Bag and Peter Yeung (Industry 4.0 Center Tour), Manuel Gruber, Julia Cuellar, Rob, Bulusu, Hubertus Oswald (MCC Presentation).

 

#STEM #PremiumHubCoE
